conclusion: To determine whether the gas absorbs or releases heat when moving from state A to state B in the P-V diagram of the Stirling cycle, follow these steps:
The process A→B is described as isothermal, meaning it occurs at a constant temperature.

For an ideal gas undergoing an isothermal process, the internal energy (U) remains constant because the temperature is constant. This implies that any change in energy must be due to work and heat transfer.
In an isothermal expansion (from A to B), the gas does work on the surroundings as it expands.
This work can be calculated by the area under the P-V curve during the expansion.
The first law of thermodynamics states that the change in internal energy (ΔU) is equal to the heat added to the system (Q) minus the work done by the system (W).

premise: Since ΔU = 0 in an isothermal process.
Since the gas does work on the surroundings (W is positive), and there is no change in internal energy (ΔU = 0).
conclusion: The heat added to the system (Q) must also be positive. This means heat is absorbed by the gas.

premise: During the isothermal expansion from state A to state B, the gas absorbs heat from the surroundings.
conclusion: The gas absorbs heat when moving from state A to state B.
